These protections helped nearly 500,000 Black people vote in the 1870s. They also helped 2,000 Black public officials get elected.

Unfortunately, they would not last.
After the Civil War, Congress passed laws to enforce the 13th, 14th, and 15th amendment. These were some of the first laws in America to protect voting rights, and they worked.
